column11: Review Text

Visiting for the second or third time. A great experience indeed. Marveling at the talent, energy and resilience of the artist called Bharana, who was an engineer occupied with building Kalawewa reservoir, and as a hobby ended up turning out this great creation in 7 years, which now stands for over 1500 years.

Our guide explained the amazing story of this engineer who built the dam and who in his spare time played the hammer and chisel. One of the oldest and most beautiful in the country according to some. This Buddha is huge, imposing, beautiful. It opens to meditation. This place is quiet, it distils serenity: take a detour!

It is an impressive Buddha statue carved from the stone.It is not how the photos currently show, but they have put up a kind of rain tent...so it does not look so impressive to me. You have to pay 1,500 rupees.

column8: Awukana Buddha Statue: A Journey Through Sri Lanka's Ancient Art and Spiritual Heritage
column11: Welcome to one of Sri Lanka‚Äôs most remarkable historical landmarks, the Awukana Buddha Statue! As your guide, I‚Äôm excited to share the incredible story behind this ancient masterpiece, which has stood the test of time for over 1,500 years. Standing at an impressive 42 feet, this awe-inspiring statue was carved out of a single granite rock during the reign of King Dhatusena in the 5th century. The craftsmanship here is extraordinary‚Äînotice how the robes seem to flow naturally over the Buddha's body, even though it‚Äôs all carved from stone. This statue represents the ‚ÄúAsisa Mudra,‚Äù a gesture of blessing, and you‚Äôll feel a sense of calm and spirituality just by looking at the serene expression on the Buddha‚Äôs face. As we stand here in the peaceful surroundings near the Kala Wewa reservoir, it‚Äôs easy to imagine how this site was not only a place of worship but also a hub of culture and art in ancient Sri Lanka. The skill and precision of the stone carving are a testament to the expertise of the craftsmen of that time. This was not just a religious monument but a statement of artistic achievement. What makes the Awukana statue even more fascinating is that it has been well-preserved over the centuries, despite being exposed to the elements. You‚Äôll be amazed at how much detail still remains, especially in the folds of the robes and the delicate facial features. For any visitor to Sri Lanka, this is a must-see destination‚Äînot just for its religious significance but also for its historical and artistic value. Whether you're a history buff, a spiritual traveler, or simply someone who appreciates magnificent art, the Awukana Buddha Statue offers a unique glimpse into Sri Lanka‚Äôs rich cultural past. I hope you enjoy your visit and leave with a deeper understanding of Sri Lanka‚Äôs ancient heritage!

column8: Little known, impressive and in a very nice area.
column11: Stunning Buddha sculpture standing, original and typical of Sri Lanka, on an immense stone, still united to the mother rock. Environment of very traditional villages with interesting customs such as drying wheat on the road. Visit in August at 11:00 with no one...

Avukana Buddha statue is generally considered the pinnacle of Anuradhapura era Buddha Statues. Believed to have been constructed in the 5th century AD during the timea of King Datusena, standing at over 14 meters, it will amaze you with its life like features, intricate detailing and the sheer scale. You can reach Avukana from Thambuttegama, Galewela as well as from Kekirawa side or even via Kurunegala- hiripitiya-Madagalla. A lot of roads around the area were being newly carpeted at the time we visited. Even the access road to the avukana statue was in good condition and you can go down the same road up to kalawewa. Once you go down the access roads, the Google maps will say you have reached the location when there is nothing in sight! Drive a couple of hundred meters forwards and you will come to a place that looks like park a with small shops etc. There is ample parking and some small shops selling snacks and drinks. From the main road, there is only a small climb up to the statue. The place is maintained quite well by the army.

column8: Visit in the morning hours as it's peaceful and calm
column11: We went to this place in the early morning. All carved on a stone. There's a great story to this place. Surrounding was calm and peaceful. We mediated around 2 hours at this place.

column8: Large statue carved into the rock
column11: It was the first stop on our tour of Sri Lanka. We were still dazed from the plane trip, we were catapulted into this oasis of quiet, few tourists, several faithful. We adapted to the rules in force in Buddhist temples, barefoot, knee-length trousers, shoulders covered. Don't take photos with people with their backs to the Buddha, it's not allowed. High entry price, compared to the complex which is not very large.
Beautiful Buddha and a must-see, they say it is carved from a single stone, honestly, amazingly beautiful. The bad thing was that the sun caught us in the face...
Not worth a visit. You have to pay about 1500 rupies for each person. The statue is covered by a roof. In a few minutes you have seen everything.
It can be considered as a masterpiece of idol artists in our country.A place where the mind rests...

The statue itself is well preserved and nice. Now it is under a roof, which makes it look less impressive than in older photos. The entrance fee of 1000 LKR is extremely high and totally undeserved for a couple of minutes of looking at a single statue. Makes the whole experience something better to avoid. Also, the roads in the area are in very bad condition, as a minimum there are 20-30 minutes bumpy ride if you decide to visit the site.

This is a magnificent example of our ancient craftsmanship. This is an amazing example of a well preserved standing Buddha statue. It‚Äôs a calm and peaceful place. Since this is a religious place behave well dress accordingly and pay your respects.

I visited with our parents and my 8 years old son. It's recommended to go in the early morning since these days are very hot in the day time. We worshipped very peacefully because it's not very crowded. There's a information desk and the Policeman there was very helpful. Make sure to visit Raswehera Temple,  same kind of Buddha statue there.Also a  Good educational tour for my son.
I‚Äôm sure there was good reason to put a cover over this but it spoils the beauty and photography of the statue.

Likely dating from about the 8th c A.D., this 43' statue is striking. The Buddha is in the blessing position re his hands. The statue looks human but has transcendental, divine elements. The statue has a roof overhead for protective purposes but it does detract from the beauty of the artistic work. The lotus plinth or base was carved from a different piece of rock. We were there during a torrential downpour. On returning, there was an area to wash your feet and a little cloth on your shoes to dry your feet; classy.

We stopped here on the way from Anuradhapura to Sigiriya. Foreigners have to pay Rs. 1000 while locals walk in free. I asked the Buddhist priest if the Central Cultural Fund decides on the fees for which he gave a vague answer... When I repeated the question (upto here politely) he became quite angry and we exchanged some heated words! Thereafter he calmed down and spoke to us by the Buddha Statue. It is absurd to charge Rs. 1000 for a 5min visit to the statue.... And clearly the money was collected by the priest to improve the condition of his dwelling. Charges at Buduruwagala was Rs. 364. Which we thought was reasonable.
Worth visiting. According to the history it's done in mid 5th century AD. During King Dhatusena (Father of king Kashyapa who made Sigiriya Rock Fortress). Entrance fee for a foreigner is Rs1000 each.

Near the village of Aukana in Anuradhapura district, stands the tallest Buddha statue in Sri Lanka. (12 m in height) Carved out from a granite cliff by just a narrow piece of rock in the fifth century during the reign of king Dhathusena. The statue still in extremely good condition. The features and details are very sharp and clear. When you go to visit Avukana statue from from Habarana or Kakirawa or Dambulla on your way, you will pass Kalawewa tank. The atmosphere of Kalawewa tank will add more peace to your mind to visit or worship the statue. When you go to visit this statue bring some flowers to offer if respect Buddhism. Enjoy your tour! Thanks!
Pilgrims visit the statue from all parts of the country and the Avukana statue has now become a popular tourist attraction in Sri Lanka.
Had a full day pilgrimage tour to Anuradhapura sacred city. You should not miss to visit Avukana Buddha statue.It was a great construction.

Great job done by the craftsman. The Statue was made out of a huge granite rock and it is so beautiful. Now they have made a roof in order to protect the statue from the wind and rain. Recommend to any tourist who is interested in the history of Sri Lanka and Buddhism.

This large standing Buddha statue, carved from the granite cliff over 1500 years ago is well worth the brief stop as you make your way to other historic destinations.  This is the largest statue of its type in Sri Lanka, and it's a true work of art.

The 12 meters statue of a standing Buddha was masterfully carved out of granite stone sometime in the 5th century. Apparently it is one of the best examples of a standing statue in Sri Lanka, thus quite popular, although at the time of our visit there was no one else there. Very much worth a short stop...

Situated in north central province close to kekirawa Passing the huge tank in Kalawewa you can reach the place. Here you can see a stormy statue of Lord Buddha. its very big and the work is so neat and wonderful The important thing is that he did it with out any sophisticated machines or equipment s This is a must in your list of attraction

The Avukana Buddha statue is almost 12 m high and is carved out from a granite cliff. it is almost free-standing , being joined to the cliff by just a narrow piece of rock. It is commonly believed that this statue was constructed in the fifth century CE , during the reign of King Dathusena. In extremely good condition with its features and details still very sharp and clear. I would like to pay my thanks for the authorities which maintain that place. And I'm very much thankful to my driver Mr Mihiraj to show me that place without any request from my side. We had a nice quick lunch near the statue in the bank of nice lake (A tank according to him) named Kala wewa with it's nice breeze. I think he understood who am I. I enjoyed this visit a lot. Thanks nice Sri Lanka and nice man Mihiraj.
I had visited Aukana.it was a nice place to visit as Buddhist.on the way to Aukana nature is should have to take a fresh breath.

If you are up in the Cultural Quarter - this is a "must do" location to visit. The statue is considered to be one of best examples of standing buddhas in Sri Lanka and it is really impressive. It stands over 40 ft tall and is carved out of a granite cliff in the 5th century. The statue is attached in places to the cliff and is really well carved ( especially the detail of the robe). A modern "roof" has been build over the statue and it does take away from it a bit - but it does keep it safe from erosion. Elsewhere on the site is a small stupa with a buddha statue (hidden behind a vertical pole and also a really pretty hand dug pond/reservoir.

Interesting place, but the Reswehera Buddha at Sesseruwa is better in my opinion. This statue is also now spoiled by the metallic roof (necessary to preserve the statue), a massive structure. Worth to visit if you are passing by.
Avukana is the tallest Buddha statue in Sri Lanka carved out of one single rock during 459 - 477 AD . It shows the pose of Asisa Mudra of Lord Buddha.
Me and my family visited this place according to our guid's suggestions, after visited we understood this is a very important place to visit. I can recommend aukana.

It's about 45 minutes drive from dambulla. A large standing position granite statue of Buddha. If you are in dambulla or anuradhapura and have a couple of hours to spare may be check it out. The tourist ticket price is 1000lkr

In the north central province of Srilanka , we come across this  colossus Buddha statue in the Awakana village on the Dambulla- Anuradhapur highway. The 40feet (nearly) Buddha statue in the standing posture in the blessing posture is carved on a huge granite boulder , around 5th Century AD. There is a proposal to construct a huge 3-tier building to inculcate the ideals of Buddhism. The workmanship on the carving , including the finely folded robes is awesome. The place , though does not attract much tourists , is really a must on a tour of Srilanka.

This ancient stone statue is nearly 50 feet high.  Incredible. The resident monk, dressed in orange robes was very welcoming & eager to speak of having met Queen Elizabeth11 & The Duke Of Edinburgh in 1981 when they visited the site.  Donations are welcomed to support ht school run nearby.

This statue is a massive standing Buddha hewn out of solid rock in the 5th or 11th century, according to who you believe.  It was a very impressive piece of history for such an ancient sculpture. Of course we had to take our shoes off to go and visit it and boy were the stones hot as it was just past the middle of the day at 36 degrees C.I would recommend wearing socks rather than bare feet.

We can see kala wewa around Avukana buddha statue! And it was calm place nice place great budhdha statue. one of greatest creation of our ancient. I would like request all to visit this place and donate as much as you can to protect and maintain for future.
According to legend, the magnificent 12m-high standing Aukana Buddha was sculpted during the reign of Dhatusena in the 5th century, v

You have to travel off from the Anuradhapura - Polonnarawa route to go there. Roads are okay but almost no signs for direction. Ticket is priced 1000 LKR for foreigners and do not visit a worth if you are not that much interested in History / Art of Sri Lanka. The statue is very detailed. Recently they have constructed a concrete table for flower offering, damaging the archeologically preserved site.

Get down from train in Avukana train station and you will get to the statue within 20 mins. The statue, which has a height of more than 40 feet (12 m), was carved out of a large granite rock face during the 5th century. It depicts a variation of the Abhaya mudra, and the closely worn robe is elaborately carved. The statue was built by King Dhathusena. There is another nearby standing statue of the Buddha, quite similar to the Avukana statue, at Sasseruwa. According to legend, the two statues are the result of a competition between a stone sculpting master and pupil. The story goes that the master constructed the Avukana statue, while the pupil made the statue at Sasseruwa. The first to complete his statue had to notify the other by ringing a bell. The master managed to complete his statue first, and won the competition. This is said to be why the Sasseruwa statue is unfinished. However the statue is very important for Buddhists. It is one of the best examples of a standing statue constructed in ancient Sri Lanka. If you are lady make sure that you wear a appropriate dress covering your shoulders and legs since this is a religious place.

The Buddha is impressive and huge, 1500 years old. If you don't need to drive too far to get here, it's worth it. But there's nothing else around so to make a special trip is unnecessary. Cost: 1000 rupees p/p.

Our guide talked nonstop but due to different accent I could hardly catch 50% of what he explained about this special Buddha site. I felt lucky and blessed by Buddha for the rest of my life. Namo Buddha üôèüôèüôè

This temple is one of the top destinations for us on our long journey to Anuradhapura.  On our way to Avukana, we drove past the Kala Wewa or Kala reservoir. This is an ancient reservoir built by King Dhathusena. The Avukana Buddha statue was created during the 5th century AD is positioned facing this reservoir. This standing statue with the pedestal is 13 m in height and that's about 42 feet. It is a masterpiece of Sinhala Buddhist construction. The closely worn robe is elaborately carved and the left hand clutches the robe at the left shoulder. We did not encounter any entry fees. We made a donation. Therefore, if you don't, please consider donating what you can to the temple. If you can spare the time, drive around the reservoir and feel the tranquility of paradise. See photo 'Road to paradise'.
Peaceful and quiet place. How did this carved statue get built all those centuries ago. Serenity reigns at this Buddha

Avukana is a huge beautiful Buddha statue carved from a piece of rock, more than a thousand years ago. It is a little difficult to get to. I visited en route to Anuradhapura. The driver took a while to find the place. Entrance is 500 Rp. I was the only visitor. Peaceful and quiet. There is also a small white stupa in the temple compound.

Make every effort to see this statue carved from the rock behind it. Since it faces east, it would be best to see it in the morning, so the sunlight falls on it directly. Even though we saw it in the late afternoon, it was incredibly moving. Note that there is a protective roof scaffolding over it now that detracts somewhat, but I am glad there is now some protection from the elements. While not the tallest standing Buddha in the country, it is remarkably well preserved. It stood out as one of our top Buddhist sites in our 16-day tour of Sri Lanka focused on the World Heritage Buddhist sites. Include it as part of your cultural triangle tour as it is not duplicated anywhere else!

This is a unique Buddha statue. It is located at a rather remote place. The statue featured the 5th century art where it was carved out marvelous from a huge stone and standing tall. There is a big bodhi tree in front where prayer will pay homage and offer chanting of sutra to calm the mind, cleanse the body and speech. There is a small entrance and foreigner have to buy a ticket of Rp750 to enter.
It's a marvelous historic creation. 40 feet high Lord Buddha's statue carved on granite rock. Recommend to visit day time to see this beautiful statue.

During our trip to Sri Lanka we saw many beautiful carvings and statues. The Avukana Buddha statue is the most beautiful. The carving of the robes makes it feel like a sheer robe flowing over the body. The detail is amazing. The size of the statue - and it's carved out of the stone mount behind it is spectacular. This is one site in Sri Lanka that should not be missed.
If you're heading north from Kandy don't miss this truly impressive site. It's just south of Anarapadhura.

A short walk up a sloping road from the main road to the ticket office, you have no idea what you will be faced with. Even after passing through the 'shoes off' kiosk you can't see the buddha itself. Then you emerge and are hit by the sheer size and beauty of this statue, carved in a single piece from the rock face more than 1500 years ago. If there is a downside to this place it is that it has become a victim of the SL government's attempt to protect key monuments by building hideous metal frames and roofs around precious pieces (presumably to protect them from the weather) which do distract and detract from the incredible sculptures.

Not as touristy as some of the other religious sites. This sculpture is so beautiful and impressive you'll look up at it in awe. It's a very tranquil place. A little out of the way but worth the effort to get there.

Before going to Sigiriya, we wanted to visit the sacred site at Avukana.  You can't imagine how the statue stands inside a gully of rock.You begin your journey by walking up steps and then once on the temple grounds you view the head which is on the same level as you are walking.  It is only when you get close that you realize you are high on a cliff looking down and across at this marvelous sculpture.  We were very appreciative that Mr. Hetti, from Hetti Tours,  went out of his way and took the time to show us this Wonder.

Aukana Standing Buddha was the first trip in our 1 week vacation in Sri Lanka. This place would be about 1-2 hours drive by a van from Anuradhapura, Habarana or Dambulla; suggest to plan for this based on the time available in your itinerary. After an hour's drive from Anuradhapura we arrived close to the site and were stopped by the village kids that the van cannot go further to the site owing to flash floods. They told us that we could walk across the train track and the rail bridge to get to the site. The excitement to view a tall standing Buddha overcame our risk assessment skills and we took the challenge with 2 elders of about 70 years and kids 11 & 6 years. However, the crossing was not as easy as we thought. The steps between the rail's sleeper logs were sometimes more than 2 feet apart crossing them with a stream of madly rushing water below was not at all easy. The thought of missing a step and falling into the gushing water below was scary, besides creating a vertigo effect to make the adrenalin rush more. The kids who were skilled to run across the bridge held our hands and made it possible to cross as we had no option to retreat half way through! Finally we got to see the tall standing pose of Buddha carved out of a single rock and it was a calming effect for the mad adrenalin rush until that moment. The statue should be easily between 35 to 40 feet tall. We did not have any guide with us and since there was no details on the historical information about the site, we could just enjoy the marvel of the work but without details backing them.

This place is off the beaten track and not known to many typical tourist tours and drivers. It is in a gorgeous area, very quiet and hilly and green (surprise surprise!) it is an idyllic village. The statue is a short walk up a hill and over some steps and is a working temple with monks present and a shrine to the Hindu Gods. The Buddha is huge standing upright and just away from the rock, it was originally carved from the rock face behind it. It is a very peaceful place. If you're into meditation this would be a good place to have some 'me time'.

A little off the beaten path, between Mihintale and Dambulla, you will find the master piece of stone masonry that is Avukana Buddha. A close to 12 m high stone buddha carved in one piece out of the rock, including its lotus seat. Legend has it that the carving was a competition between a master and his student who started a stone buddha somewhere in the vicinity. The master won the competition which is what you see today in a truly masterful and artistic display. The posture of the 'blessing buddah' is rare and a sight to be seen. The area does not offer much in terms of services and is all the more peaceful for it. Unless you happen to come along with a bus load full of pilgrims, you will have the place to yourself. Renovations are almost finished, the buddha can be looked at without scaffolding hindering the views (but for the new canopy protecting the buddha from the elements), currently there are only works done at the monastery building. The little chapel is open for prayer. The food stalls at the bus stop (public transportation possible) is a regular zoo and should be avoided. With a little time on the road, plan to take a stop at Kala Wewa, a huge lake which offers bathing/swimming and feeding for the more leisurely pilgrim.

The most well preserved stone crafted statue. Crafted from a whole piece of rock, details such as face features, hands, robes and so on is clearly seen till today. One fascinating secret is, rain drops flow directly from the nose will drop correctly and precisely on the center of the feet!

Entrance fee is 750 LKR. At the moment there are reconstruction works but you still can go down to the bottom of the statue and anywhere else, but making good pictures is quite difficult. It is really impressive and worth seeing it. It's a small place and you won't need much time to visit. When we visited the Aukana Buddha, not too much people where there.

We were quite disappointed to find scaffolding up at the site. If we had known this we would not have taken the detour. It is clearly an impressive rock carving, but the unfathomably large amount of scaffolding in front of the statue detracted significantly from the experience. I suggest you check ahead and hopefully someone will post here when the situation is back to normal.

Located in a slightly out of the way site close to Kala weva this is of interest to all those who have an appreciation of Buddhism or indeed ancient history. Carved out of rock in the 5th century slightly before the creation of the now destroyed Bamiyan statues in Afganistan, it is a wonder to behold. Similar to Gal Viharaya it continues to hold religious significance which gives the place an atmosphere uniquely different from some of the other historical world wonders such as Petra, Rome or Delos. The site is quite small and unassuming with a little temple but with little else that caters to mass tourism. Long may it remain this way!

This is an absolute must to see. Off the beaten track but close to Anuradhapura it is a small detour on a drive to or from Sirigiya. It may also be visited on a drive between Anuradhapura and Polonnaruwa. Up a couple of flights of steps is this 12 metre high statue carved out of the rock. Indeed it is still attached at the back. The Buddha is standing in the blessing pose with one hand (right) in profile. What is worth noting is the plumpness of arms and legs. This is quite different from many other Buddhas. The statue was devoid of tourists making it a calm place to visit what is considered to be a masterpiece. It bears a passing resemblance to those Buddhas destroyed in Afghanistan.

Decided to visit Avukana since I was in the Dambulla area for some other work. The last time I visited this place was about 10 years ago. Drove to Kekirawa and took the Thalawa road. Then went along the Kalawewa reservoir.  Asked for directions at junctions. It was around 2.30 PM when I visited the place. Just a few foreigners and about 2 locals. I had the entire place for my self. I cannot explain the feeling . It was so quite , calm and relaxing. Stayed for about 1 hour and made a small donation to the temple. A place worthy of a visit definitely.

The standing Buddha at Aukana ,is so life like that you expect it to move at any moment !!! 12 metres high the detail is amazing .One of the finest example of Buddhist sculpture  !!The site is well kept ,with the exception of the toilets !!

Aukana means 'sun-eating' as the statue's finely-carved features are best seen with the first rays of light. The statue is between Polonnaruwa and Anuradhapura on the Kekirawa Road. The statue carved out of a living rock stands at a height at 12 meters and is the tallest Buddha statue in existence. There is a close resemblance to the Bamiyan Buddha statue in Afghanistan. Traveling to and from the site could take 2 hours from either end (Anuradhapura/ Polonnaruwa).
